dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wedding GUESTS in hoop skirts and morning suits roam abou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten BRIDESMAIDS clad in fuchsia primp and gossip. A FLOWE GIRL frolics amidst balloons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room of the consummate beauty pageant contestant. Ina white hoop skirt stands belle of the ball DELILAH MACINTO early 20s. Tending to the bride are: mother MIRABELLE, a domineering matriarch; bridesmaid CHARLENE, Delilah's older, heavier sister; and bridesmaid MARNEY, fetching and shallow.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I can't believe my weddin' day is finally here. In an hour, I'll be married to the man o' my dreams. Somebody pinch me. Charlene pinches her, hard.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Ow! I meant, figuratively.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: I pinched your figure, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (pirouettes) How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Like you crap diamonds.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: Marney. I don't appreciate such language in my house.

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mrs. M. It just sort of... (eyes Delilah in mirror) slid out. Delilah holds... then bursts into giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stamps her shoe) Enough of that! This is your wedding day for heaven's sake. Not some tawdry night in a cheap motel. Charlene, doesn't your sister look beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: (admitting defeat) Yes, Momma. She crouches to adjust Delilah's skirt.

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: I feel like a whale in this thing, just waiting to be harpooned.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: Tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: (pats Marney's arm) You're not a whale, Honey. She brushes past Charlene, who reddens.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: It's only for a few hours. Then y'all can get naked, hop on an usher, and jump in the pool.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: They will do no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I'm just teasin', Momma. Try and relax. You're makin' me nervous.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: A bride is supposed to be nervous on her wedding day.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: Like it's a law or something?

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: It is a law. Your family comes bearing gifts. Don't you want to make a good impression on them?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: How many candle holders you figure you'll get?  Mirabelle

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Enough to start my own cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what I'd want... a Naloni Bucintoro watch. That's right.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Aren't you forgettin' somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Your husband, the guy you'd be marryin'. Aren't the gifts s'posed to be for both of you?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Oh please. How much enjoyment is he gonna get out of a china bowl, or a crystal flute sitting in a cabinet? So he might as well be not enjoying something that makes me happy.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: We have a philosopher among us. Any idea when your big day will come?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: I kicked Trent to the curb two months ago, so it probably won't be in the next few weeks. gives Marney a look of disdain.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Serves him right for what he done.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: What'd he do?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Made a pass at my mother. I'm still surprised she told me.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Should've set the bastard on fire after somethin' like that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: That's not the answer. Living well's the best revenge.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh? Is that what you did after Howard?  Charlene narrows her eyes at Delilah and marches out.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: That was a bit below the corset, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Momma. After today, she'll have two weeks to get over it. (to Marney) "Fore I lose another bridesmaid, you mind takin' one o' the programs down to Kelvin?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Sure. Getting a little humid in here. She meanders to the bureau. Ogles the program.

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Oh no. Did he have to pose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah stands next to her bridegroom. He puts up his duk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bridegroom shadowboxes in front of a mirror. KELVIN WINGFIELD, 30, the body of a flyweight, the ego of a heavyweight. A pencil moustache outlines his upper lip.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: You want some o' this? Huh? You want some o' this, Bitch? Cuz I know you can't handle some o' this. The BEST MAN, 20s, trades barbs with three ushers: BUCK, CHUCK and TUCK. They all swig longneck beers.

dialogues.speaker: BEST MAN
dialogues.text: Kick that chump's ass, Kel. The ushers laugh. A knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Beers. Finish 'em. Now. The groomsmen guzzle, toss bottles in the trash. Kelvin fixes his hair in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Come in. Marney sashays in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah wanted me to give you this.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: The program. Can you get with it?

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Bring it here. Let me see it. He motions to his entourage to leave. Marney stomps over. Best Man shuts the door on his way out.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I didn't get a chance to see it. (admires his picture) What do you think of it?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Pretty weak if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Weak? There's a word I don't like. Especially from someone so... eye- grabbing.

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Please. I feel like Orca coming out of the closet in this thing.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: (chuckles) No, I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: You're a good liar. I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I'm a fighter, Marney. I can't stand for lies and I can't stand for weakness. I pride myself on my strength. (puffs out chest) My agility. (gyrates like a Chippendale dancer) And my ability to... move things. (presses his junk against her) Marney lets out a little squeak. They lock lips, grope at each other like teenagers in a back seat. Kelvin spins Marney around, lifts up her skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These hoop skirts were a great idea. Surprised there even was a war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah's alone, admiring her engagement ring.

dialogues.speaker: FLOWER GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Let go!

dialogues.speaker: BOY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Big Baby!

dialogues.speaker: FLOWER GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Stop it! I'm telling! Delilah scoots into the

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS HALLWAY
dialogues.text: just as Flower Girl slaps the RING BEARER, the seed of Ch but a smidgen taller, in the face.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Hey! Stop it you two! Ring Bearer slaps Flower Girl back, knocking her down. Sh immediately cries.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Shame on you! Don't you ever do that again! Ring Bearer farts with his mouth at Delilah and scrams.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Come back here, you! Don't you ever hit a lady! You hear me?! She stoops to Flower Girl, whose face is puffy pink.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Hey, Sweetie. It's alright. Wanna come with me? Come on, let's go. She helps her up, escorts her into

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: On the way in, Delilah swipes a hairbrush and a tissue of her bureau. She directs Flower Girl to a small platform that stands before an ornate full-length mirror.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: We're gonna fix you up, good as new. (hands tissue) Here you go, Sweetie.  Flower Girl wipes her eyes. Delilah stands behind her, brushing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Wanna know somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: FLOWER GIRL
dialogues.text: (sniffling) What? She looks up at Delilah's reflection.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I ain't ever seen a prettier flower girl in my entire life. You know that? 'Deed, it's true. Look at this hair. Bet it drives all the boys wild. They're just not sure why yet. Wait until it gets long. You'll have to beat 'em off with a curlin' iron. There. All better. Now, wanna come see me get married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guests chat boisterously on rows of folding chairs, separated by an aisle of manicured grass. A brass QUINTET occupies the final row.

dialogues.speaker: TUBA
dialogues.text: Try not to screw it up this time.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH HORN
dialogues.text: Blow it out your arse.

dialogues.speaker: CENTER STAGE
dialogues.text: The MINISTER, 50s, emerges in a gray suit and red bow tie Smiles at the large gathering. Kelvin appears, looking a bit disheveled, buttons his jac The Quintet plays PRELUDE MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Good. Thank you for asking. Feeling a bit nervous?

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: No, actually. I'm quite relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Splendid. The PROCESSION begins. Buck escorts Mirabelle and KELVIN'S MOM, 50s, a museum o Silicone and collagen, to their seats in the front row. Best Man follows, arm in arm with the Maid of Honor, Char He waves like he's just arrived on Oscar night. Chuck and Tuck strut down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: You and Jezebel thinking of getting married?

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Her name's Jesselyn, jackass.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Jesselyn Jackass. I like it. The Bridesmaids, including a rumpled Marney, parade in pa Behind them, the Ring Bearer, looking sweaty and confused And then, the Flower Girl. She freckles the aisle with magnolia petals. Ring Bearer turns and gives her a dirty look. She proudly produces her tongue for him. A pregnant pause. Anticipation builds amongst the Guests. The Quintet strikes up Mendelssohn's WEDDING MARCH. Delilah appears with her father, SAMUEL, 50s, silver hair and a downward smile, a keeper of many secrets. The bride carries a bouquet of pink magnolias. They proceed down the aisle. Flashbulbs and smiles light the tent. Kelvin steals a look at Marney, who blushes.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: (whispers) Think they did it?

dialogues.speaker: BEST MAN
dialogues.text: Course they did, look at her. She's as pink as a baboon's ass. The Minister turns to the Best Man, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: BEST MAN
dialogues.text: Sorry, Your Honor. Kelvin sneers at Mirabelle and Charlene, both looking blo and uncomfortable as they fan themselves. Delilah and Samuel arrive at the altar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gives this woman in marriage?

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: I do. Samuel kisses Delilah's cheek, puts her hand in Kelvin's. He takes a seat next to Mirabelle.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Dearly Beloved, we are gathered together here in the sight of God to join together this Man and this Woman in holy Matrimony. If any man- or woman- can show just cause, why they may not lawfully be joined together, let him- or her- now speak or forever hold their peace. Marney has a COUGHING fit. A murmur ripples through the crowd. Delilah scowls at her.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Is she gagging on something?

dialogues.speaker: BEST MAN
dialogues.text: But he's standing all the way over here.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Shut up. Kelvin and Delilah face each other.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Kelvin, wilt thou have this woman as thy wedded wife, to live together after God's ordinance in the holy estate of Matrimony? Wilt thou love her, comfort her, honor, and keep her in sickness and in health; and, forsaking all others, keep thee only unto her, so long as ye both shall live?

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I... been doing some thinking. GASPS from the crowd nearly bring down the tent.

dialogues.speaker: USHERS
dialogues.text: Woops.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: What?  10.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Look... Delilah's eyes bug as Kelvin searches for the right words

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I'm a fighter, Delilah. I can't stand for lies and I can't stand for weakness. I pride myself on --

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: What in God's name are you talkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I think I got a few more good rounds in me. And I just don't think I'm ready to hang up my belt. Capeesh?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I'll show you capeesh. She swings at him with her left. Kelvin slips her punch. A right from Delilah. He slips it again. She winds up and delivers a roundhouse left. Kelvin slips her punch for a third time, only this time, Delilah trips her train and collapses. She CLONKS her head on the stage

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: My God! Is she alright?! Mirabelle faints. Delilah's out like a light. The Ministe stoops down to assist. He peers up at Kelvin but he's gon The bridegroom leaves with his entourage.

dialogues.speaker: BEST MAN
dialogues.text: Another TKO from the K-man. The Guests stand with their mouths agape. Some shout: "Wh are you going?" And "You forgot your bride." Children Boo

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Mirabelle holds smelling salts under Delilah's nose.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (opens her eyes) Yeckh, what is that? Get that thing away from me.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: A little gratitude would be nice. I've never done this before.  11. Delilah sits up. Nearly everyone has left. It begins to sink in: The Wedding That Never was. Charlene and Marney sit in the first row looking desponde Samuel approaches Delilah, kneels down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Are you alright, Honeybee? Let me help you up.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: Leave her be! She needs to do it herself. Samuel backs off.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (slowly stands) What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: You mean you don't remember? He left you. The one wearing the tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Thanks, Momma. That helps.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: I think Delilah could do without the snide remarks right now.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: What do you know about it? Do you know what went into putting on this wedding day?!

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: I think I do. I paid for it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: That's just marvelous. And what did I invest? Nothing at all, right?! Only the fancy wedding invitations, and the registry, and that Godforsaken rehearsal dinner --

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: I just think --

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: Those God-awful programs, and the fittings, and the million alterations on those bloody hoop skirts, and the guest list, and the thank you cards --

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Don't you think --  12.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: And the photographer, and the videographer, and the caterer, and the minister, and the florist, and the band, and that fat slob chauffeur brother of yours, AND a five thousand dollar cake that nobody ate!

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Yes, but, this wasn't Delilah's fault. Mirabelle huffs and storms off. Samuel watches her leave. He takes a seat, dizzy and disconcerted. Delilah turns to her sister and Marney.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: This isn't really happenin', right?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Honey. A hint of a smile appears on Charlene's face. She looks away, trying to hide it.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Is somethin' funny?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Then why are you smilin'?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: Nothing. It's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I bet I look pretty funny, huh? "When Beauty Queen Weddings Go Wrong." Right? Fox is gonna be all over my ass now. Real funny, Charlene. Charlene can't hold it any longer. She bursts out laughin

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Delilah. (scampers away)

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Some family. Samuel gives her a pained look. Delilah sits next to Marn  13.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: This was so humiliatin'. There ain't no comin' back from somethin' like this.

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: You will, Sweetie. Might not feel like it now, but... you'll see. The sun will come up tomorrow, right? Isn't that what the 1i'l orphan girl says?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I just wanna beat him senseless.

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: You could do that. But that'll just get you thrown in jail for assault "n battery. It's not worth it.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: How could he do that to me?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Honey, men like Kelvin are a dime a baker's dozen. Crying over somebody like that, well... that's just foolish if you ask me. You can do better. Delilah spies the wedding cake in the corner of the tent.

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: I swear to you... Delilah charges at the cake like a belle out of hell. She flails at it, stirring up a whirlwind of icing.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (mocking Kelvin) You been doin' some thinkin', huh?! You couldn't think up a brain fart! I'll give you somethin' to think about ! Strawberry mousse splatters all over her hoop skirt as sh punches away. Samuel buries his head in his hands. Delilah snatches the figurine of Kelvin atop the cake and flings it into the trees.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Smallest pecker I've ever seen! Marney raises her eyebrows, confused by the comment. Deli looks down at herself, thoroughly covered in cake. Perhap a moment of clarity. Then, shamelessly, she licks herself  14. Mirabelle and Charlene pop back into the tent. They get a eyeful of Delilah going to town on the cake. Her indulgen verges on pornography.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: (aghast) Oh my word.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: (salivating) Oh my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remnants of a wedding cake and dress decorate the floor. Delilah lies dormant on her bed, face first into her pill The ALARM CLOCK goes off: the sound of a Boxing Fight Bel Delilah reaches her hand out and shuts it off.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Delilah, still in bed. One-gallon buckets of ice cream ha been hollowed out. They sit sadly on the floor by the bed Her phone rings, Delilah reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDESMAID, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Delilah? It's me, Cassandra. How're you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I'm fine. An empty pint of ice cream falls off the end of the bed. silver spoon rattles on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDESMAID, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Listen... I'm not gonna be able to make it to that picnic on Sunday...

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: But we've been plannin' that for a month.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDESMAID, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I know, but... something just came up, and uhh... I'm sorry, but I can't.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh. What came up?  15.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDESMAID, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Umm... I'm just not comfortable talking about it.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Okay. Bye... (hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Delilah, still in bed. Pizza boxes have joined the empty ice cream containers on the floor. One box, half-eaten, sits squarely on Delilah's wedding dress. Her alarm clock goes off. Delilah flings it across the ro She returns her face to the pillow and shuts her eyes. Slowly, her eyes open again. They focus ona

dialogues.speaker: FRAMED PICTURE
dialogues.text: of Kelvin boxing in the ring. Delilah picks it up and studies it. An epiphany.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Assault 'n battery, my hot ass. From under her bed, she pulls out the Yellow Pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah saunters in. Her hair a tangled, greasy mess. Mirabelle and Charlene eat breakfast at the table.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Mornin'. How y'all doin'?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: We're okay. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (strolls to counter) I feel rejuvenated. 'Deed, I do. There's a renaissance goin' on in my pajamas as we speak.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: Okaaay. She turns to her mother like Delilah might be nuts.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: Delilah, I didn't raise you to talk like that.  Delilah pours herself a glass of orange juice.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: You know somethin', Momma? You are ab-so-lute-ly right. You taught me to speak proper, act like a lady, drown all my sorrows in iced tea, and take action when the need calls for it. And you know what? That's exactly what I'm gonna do.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about, for heaven's sake?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (downs her juice) Y'all are lookin' at the first female boxer in all the MacIntosh family. Mirabelle EXPLODES with laughter. Charlene looks at her mother terrified.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That's right. You laugh. But I'm tellin' you right now... I'm gonna box my way up the ranks and beat the bejesus outta his skinny-little ass. Give 'im a taste of humiliation he won't soon forget.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: You're saying you're gonna box Kelvin.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That's exactly what I'm sayin', 0 Sister O' Mine.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: That's insane. He'd kill you.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That's where you're wrong, my sweet 1i'l dumplin'. Hell hath no fury like a beauty queen scorned. You just remember that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah parks her pink 1970 Mini Cooper in the lot. wears a fuchsia sweat suit and matching makeup.

The THUMPING of heavy bags, the STACCATO hammering of spe bags. A few weight benches sit in a far corner.  17. In an 18' x 18' ring, female boxer SLICE, 30s and lean wi reddish hair, spars with an OPPONENT. Ringside is TANDY BURROWS. She's 30, buff with a harsh Bo accent, her glinty eyes have seen more than their share.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Christ, Slice, keep your chin down! Delilah flits in carrying her fuchsia purse. Unsure where to go, she approaches Tandy.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Where do I --

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Can't you fuckin' see I'm busy?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm... sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Go pahk your ass ova there. Delilah ambles to the opposite side of the ring. Many of the GYM-GOERS give her the once-over. TWO of them snigger as they toss a medicine ball back and forth. In the ring, Slice is throttled by two left hooks. Delila looks on as Slice retaliates, hammering her Opponent.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Take it easy, you're losing your shit! Slice doesn't seem to hear, or care. Throws a rabbit punc

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Time! She enters the ring livid, stomps straight over to Slice.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: What did I tell you about keeping your cool?

dialogues.speaker: SLICE
dialogues.text: I wasn't pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Bull-shit. You lost it. I already told you. If you get mad, you get crazy, and if you get crazy, you're gonna end up in a hospital. I'm not having that here. This ain't about emotion. It's about heart. You better learn the difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more hard look through Slice and Tandy exits the ring A look of concern sweeps over Delilah's face.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: If you're looking for the mall, you head straight down Fahm, then --

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I'm aware where the mall is, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Whaddya want, then?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Is this your gym?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Better fuckin' believe it.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: My name's Delilah MacIntosh. It's nice to meet you. She puts out her hand, comes up empty.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: You running for office?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Nope. I'm campaignin' to be a boxer.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Good God No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the walls, a tribute to the female boxer. Tandy sits with her feet up behind a desk, squeezing a tennis ball i each hand. Delilah fills out an application on a clipboar

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I never got your name.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Tandy. So what brings a girl like you to boxing?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Well... I'm a graduate of Norton Beauty College. I've got my manicurist license, as well as my cosmetology license. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I won the Miss Georgia beauty pageant two years ago. And um, this year, I'm the Magnolia Princess.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: So... what brings a girl like you to boxing?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh. I wanted to change career paths. Uh huh. I mean, beauty's only skin deep, right? That's what they always say. 'N who knows, maybe they're right. Workin' in an office is just not my thing. I'd die if I had to sit in a cube all day, wouldn't you? Tandy looks dizzy, rubs the confusion from her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: You married? Delilah covers her engagement ring.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: No. Still single.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Well, Delilah, I gotta warn you. Boxing's a far cry from doing the friggin' catwalk. Ya follow me? It can get pretty brutal out there.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Dangit! An eyelash got in my eye. Just a sec. Slyly, she slips off her engagement ring, drops it into h pocketbook, and takes out her compact.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Lately, my eyelashes seem to have a mind o' their own. I dunno what's goin' on with them.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can see how that might be hard. She smirks at Delilah as she fishes for an eyelash.  20.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (closes her compact) Miss Tandy. I don't wanna inconvenience you, truly I don't. But I do know that if I'm gonna box, I'm sure as hellfire gonna need someone to train me.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Amen to that.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: So if it's not too much trouble... you think you might be up for it?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Why you?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, why'd you pick me?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Well um... I heard you were the best, so... why would I settle for somethin' less? Tandy raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Is my hair a mess? I'm sorry. It was real windy on the way in here.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Delilah, your resume's pretty damn impressive, I'll give you that. But I don't see how beauty pageants and a manicure license qualify you as a boxer. Boxing's about discipline. Not how pretty you look. I think you should stick with what you're good at. You're just not cut out for something like this.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: You know what? That's where you're wrong. You have any idea what it takes to win a beauty pageant? Do you? A million miles on the treadmill, all the food you can't eat, can't drink, can't smoke, don't smile too much or you might get laugh lines, takin' vitamins every day, (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: minerals, herbs, flaxseed, grapeseed, whatever-seed, and still try to find a way to sleep eight hours a night when all you can think about is that chocolate fudge cake sittin' in the fridge. Don't let the mascara and eyeliner fool you, Miss Tandy. I'm all about discipline. Now are you gonna train me or what? Tandy stares at Delilah in silence. She pulls out a notep and pen, scribbles.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: There's things you're gonna need. You can pick 'em up at Jesse's around the corner. Be here tomorrow at eight. And when you get here, could you be a little less... pink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah pushes a shopping cart loaded with neon sweats an shirts. She swipes a salmon sweatshirt off a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Nope. Too pink. A SALESPERSON, 20s, with a bump on his nose, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: How might I help you, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh, hi. I need a big bag.

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: A big bag. You know, for boxin'.

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean a heavy bag.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: Right. Follow me. (rolls eyes)  22. Delilah follows him down an aisle.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I'm gonna be a boxer. Isn't it great?

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: Um, yeah. Good for you. He stops in front of a row of black and brown heavy bags.

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: We have these here. They're well- manufactured and --

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Do you have anythin' happier?

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: Happier.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, look at these. They're all so dull-lookin'. (points to brown one) This one looks like King Kong had an accident. Who wants to see that?

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: Miss, I hope you don't mind my asking, but, why boxing? I mean, look at you. You're a knockout.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Ha!

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: Guess I stepped into that one. Look, I'm sorry, but I'm afraid we don't have any happier-looking heavy bags.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: Can I interest you in a slam, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: What?! She PUNCHES him in the nose.  23.

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: Ow! He keels over, blood trickles from his nose.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: How could you say a thing like that to me?

dialogues.speaker: BUMPY
dialogues.text: You heard me wrong. I said a SlamMan.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh. Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Delilah stands face to face with a SLAMMAN, a freestandin heavy bag shaped like the head and torso of a man. Bumpy holds a pink t-shirt to his nose. Delilah gives Sla the evil eye.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I'll take im.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah strides in wearing yellow sweats. She carries an oversized gym bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah sidles past THREE SWEATY WOMEN on their way out.

dialogues.speaker: SWEATY
dialogues.text: No breakfast, and she comes in looking like a banana split.

dialogues.speaker: SWEATIER
dialogues.text: Heh. Watch out.

dialogues.speaker: SWEATIEST
dialogues.text: I got Cool Whip at home. Delilah crams her gym bag into a locker. She turns to lea and on the wall she notices a SIGN: People Steal So Use Your Head. Delilah frowns, turns the dial on the combination lock. S pulls out her gym bag, removes her pocketbook from inside Takes out her engagement ring. She studies it, debates whether to pocket it. Tosses the ring into the locker.  24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah jumps rope. Tandy supervises. The rope gets tangled up in her feet and she tumbles.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Darnit!

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Rope's too long for ya. Stand on it with both feet and pull up. Delilah steps on the rope, the ends touch her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Let me see it. She takes the rope and shortens it.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Now try. Delilah skips. Better this time.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Why aren't we boxin'?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: You ain't in no fuckin' shape to box.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: What? I'm skinny.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Don't talk, Goldilocks. Just jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah scampers around the track, breathing heavily. Tan sips a Coke as she strolls along the grassy center.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: You know. I just have to say. That is pretty tacky. You sippin' a soda while I sweat my mammaries off.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go grab some rum from my trunk. Be right back. Delilah growls. Tandy strides away.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Tandy glides toward the track. Delilah's doubled over, searching for air.  25.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Looks like we got quite a fuckin' ways to go, don't we. Why were you running so fast? Your pantalets on fire? You gotta pace yourself. Delilah stands upright. Dark mascara streams down her che

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Fuckin' fright night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tandy idles in her Mustang. She revs the motor. Delilah trudges toward her, her cheeks still streaked. TwO BELLES look on from a parked Lexus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They slurp milk shakes.

dialogues.speaker: VANILLA
dialogues.text: You hear about what happened to her?

dialogues.speaker: STRAWBERRY
dialogues.text: Yup. It's a shame.

dialogues.speaker: VANILLA
dialogues.text: Sure is.

dialogues.speaker: STRAWBERRY
dialogues.text: Never thought she'd go Goth though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah drags in behind Tandy and heads for the locker ro

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Where ya going, Goldilocks?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: We're not done yet. Get your ass over here. I want ya to meet some o' the regulars. Tandy leads Delilah over to HANK, 20s, Korean heavyweight perfect gentleman but in no danger of making the cover of GQ; and ROMEO, 20s, African-American, with flamboyant tru Hank fields Romeo's punches with focus mitts.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Guys, this here's Delilah.  26. Slice sneers at Delilah as she destroys the heavy bag.

dialogues.speaker: SLICE
dialogues.text: You takin' in strays from the Junior League?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: I'm training Goldilocks here to box.

dialogues.speaker: SLICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I'm training my dog to shit in the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: So nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Don't let her bother you. I'm Hank. He offers a gloved hand to Delilah, and in the process mi a punch from Romeo to the kisser. It barely registers.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: It's a pleasure. Didn't that hurt?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It's no problem. He misses all the time.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Oh hush. My name's Romeo. I could never wear that color yellow, but it looks divine on you.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. I like your shorts. Where'd you find that color? I didn't see any like it at Jesse's.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Oh, I made these myself. I'd be happy to make you a --

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: (claps) Alright, ladies. This ain't a friggin' fashion show. I gotta teach Delilah here some basics. C'mere. Slice bares her teeth at Delilah, hits the bag with a flu of punches. Delilah blanches and scurries over to Tandy.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Stand in front o' the mirror so you can see what you're doing. Put your feet like this. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: (demonstrates) You're a rightie, so lead with your left. Feet shoulder-width apart. Put your fists up. Delilah crouches like she's got a load in her pants.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Don't bend so far. You're not in the bathroom. We're gonna start off slow. Just jab with your left, (jabs) punching straight out from your chin. Delilah clenches her fists and punches wildly.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Like that?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Don't clench your fist. Keep your fingers relaxed. (jabs in slow-motion) Straight from the chin. Then squeeze right before ya reach your target. Delilah jabs again. A little better.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Okay. Now this time, turn your fist a little when you punch. (shows her) Like that. So ya go from holding your fist vertical to horizontal.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (jabs again) Better?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Just keep doing it. Watch yourself in the mirror. I'm sure you can manage that. Slice stalks over to Tandy as Delilah jabs away.

dialogues.speaker: SLICE
dialogues.text: Why you humoring the poor girl?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: There's something there. It's just buried under a pile o' grits.  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vacant. Delilah treks in alone. She opens her locker and pulls out her gym bag. No sign of an engagement ring. A little grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah slogs in, flicks on the light. Sticking out like sore thumb in the center of the room is SlamMan. She drops her gym bag on the floor, notices a STICKY NOTE SlamMan's forehead: "We Need To Talk."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah, in a sea foam green sweatsuit with matching sweatband, practices her jab in front of the mirror. No makeup today. Romeo passes on his way to the ring.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Looking good there.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Thanks! Tandy emerges from her office, frowns at Delilah's form.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Keep your chin tucked, Goldilocks. This ain't no beauty pageant. Snap it out and pull it back. She stands next to Delilah in the mirror, demonstrates.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Snap it out. Pull it back. Fast. Let your punch hang and you'll fuckin' get pummeled. Delilah picks up the pace.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: You're gonna throw this punch the most, so ya sure as shit better make it count. Now show me your right. Delilah swings a roundhouse right.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: What are ya, breaking up a bar fight? Throw the punch straight. That's why they call it a straight right. (demonstrates) This time, the power's not coming from your arm.  29.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: It's not?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Nope. It's coming from your torso, (places her hands on Delilah's torso) and from your right foot when ya pivot. Delilah tries a few straight rights.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Put your back into it. Delilah adds more oomph.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Good. Explode 'n pull back. Think you're ready for the heavy bag?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: (pulls out wraps) Gimme your hands. Tandy starts wrapping Delilah's hand. Stops, inspects Delilah's long, perfectly manicured nails.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Follow me. We're going on a field trip.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Tandy pulls out a pair of tiny scissors from her desk.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Those claws gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (hides her hands) Bite your tongue. You know how much work it takes to keep my hands lookin' like this? I been cultivatin' these nails since I was fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: You wanna farm or you wanna box? Delilah stands her ground.  30.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Alright. But no boxer I know's got nails like that. (puts scissors away) I guess you know best...

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Fine, you win. She holds out her hands, shuts her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: But be quick about it. Tandy cuts Delilah's nails. Pink half-moons fall to the floor. Tandy gets to work wrapping Delilah's left hand.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Hook your thumb, wrap your wrist, your knuckles, then back to your thumb. Cross over, wrap your knuckles again, and tie it off at the wrist. You do your right. Delilah gives it a shot. She doesn't use enough tension, the wrap droops from her hand.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: You're a little too loose.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: No I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: I'm talking about the wrap.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh. Tandy takes hold of Delilah's right hand. Wraps it snug.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Now put your gloves on. Delilah slides her hand into a bag glove.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Dig your hand in there deep. Like you're fishing for change.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (pushes in deeper) Oh. What is that?  31.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I think I found a quarter.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Let's go. She leads Delilah back out to a

dialogues.speaker: HEAVY BAG
dialogues.text: next to one Slice is pounding on.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: We're starting with jabs. Remember your stance. Make sure ya hit the bag with the front of your fist, not the top. That'll hurt like a son-of- a-bitch. Delilah jabs at the bag once, then again while the bag ta away. She loses her balance and tumbles. She starts to ge up, embarrassed, and the bag hits her FLUSH on the way ba

dialogues.speaker: SLICE
dialogues.text: (laughs) You really showed him. Tandy helps Delilah up, glares at Slice.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Mind your own business. (to Delilah) Wait 'til the bag swings back before ya hit it again. Make it work for you, not the other way around.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Like this? (wallops the bag) Take that! (again) And that!

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Good. But don't get so pissed off. Clean out your ears, cuz this is important. A boxer who goes in mad, comes out hurt. Ten times out of ten. Boxing's about discipline. This ain't the WF.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: World Wildlife --  32.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Forget I said it. It's all about control. Control, and skill. That builds discipline. Capeesh? Delilah's eyes GLOW with the last word. She unleashes a diabolical flurry of punches on the heavy bag. Everyone stops and gawks at Delilah's demonstration. Except Slice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in her green sweatsuit, Delilah jogs. Exhausted, bu smiling, on a high from hitting the bag. She nears a fruit stand where fresh peaches are on displa Snags one as she passes by. Grins at the startled VENDOR.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh no! I'm stealin' a peach. Better call the fuzz. The Vendor gapes at her as she runs away. Delilah turns..

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Catch! She hurls the peach back, but misses the Vendor by a mile

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oops. Sorry! She trots back to him. Fishes a dollar from her fanny pac

dialogues.speaker: VENDOR
dialogues.text: Where I come from, throwing food is a sin. Delilah hands him another dollar.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Promise you'll light a candle for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah, in bright orange sweats and a halter top, works heavy bag. She appears tight. Tandy sidles up to her.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something? Why are ya holding your breath? Delilah stops, exhales a gust of wind. Tandy steps back, waving her hand in the air to redirect the odor.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Somebody bring this girl a Tic Tac.  33.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Sorry. Too many shallots on my grits.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Whatever. Ya still wanna breathe, right? Breathe out when ya punch. Short little wheeze. Like this. She wheezes for Delilah.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Should I call someone? Sounds like you're havin' a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Do it with me. Delilah wheezes quietly. Tandy beckons for more. She take it up a notch. Or two. Or three. The two begin to wheeze in harmony, and the Gym-goers fin it impossible to resist. EVERYONE begins to wheeze, until it sounds like the entire gym may enter into cardiac arre Tandy holds up a stop sign with her hand, the wheezing st

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: We're taking another field trip. She waves two tickets, tucks them into Delilah's halter t

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: There's a local tournament tonight. It's a good idea for you to watch. Learn how it goes down in a real fight.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That's so sweet. Y'all're comin' with me?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: How many tickets ya see there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIGHTERS trade punches in the ring. The crowd is subdued.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: The guy in blue's got a mean fuckin' left hook. Ya get yourself one o' those and you'll be dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I like how he dances.  34.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: It's called long rhythm. We'll cover that later.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: So, Tandy, what brought you to boxin'? Tandy's eyes are fixed on the fight.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: I needed a new fuckin' trail. Or path. Or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: What were you doin' before?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: I was a snake-charmer.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: What's done is done. The fight BELL dings, ending the bout. Delilah spots Marn in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Marney! Marney turns, more alarmed than surprised. She slinks ove

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Hey, Delilah. What're you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I'm here with my trainer. She's teachin' me how to box.

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Wow, sO you were serious about that?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: You know it. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: MARNEY
dialogues.text: Oh, um, I just wanted to try something different. I'll see you later, okay? She turns on a dime and skedaddles.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That sure ended in a hurry.  35.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Our next bout is in the flyweight division. In this corner, wearing red trunks, weighing in at one hundred and eleven pounds, Beau Sommers. (crowd cheers) And in this corner, wearing green trunks, weighing in at one hundred and ten pounds, Sir Kelvin Wingfield. Delilah's head whips around.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That bastard.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh. Um... the one in green.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: What about 'im?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I bought that same color the other day, that... copycattin'... jackass.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: (chortles) Whadda you care? Afraid you might clash?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: No. I'm not afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank holds the heavy bag as Delilah, in electric blue swe slugs away. Tandy looks on. Delilah's getting better, mix in some left hooks and uppercuts with her jabs.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: More power with the uppercut. Punch from your legs. Delilah dips and thrusts a whopper of an uppercut.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Good! Show me another hook. She delivers a few ineffectual left hooks.  She steps 36.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Let me show ya something. (steps up to the bag) Take the ball of your left foot, and plant it like you're putting out a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Good idea. I hate cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Then pivot your body to the right. Legs, hips, back. All of it. Like a gate swinging from a post. (throws a few hooks) out of the way and Delilah takes a crack at it.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Don't worry about looking funny. Tuck your hand to your chest when ya come around. Snap it out, and recover. Don't leave yourself open. Delilah generates more torque as she practices her hook. Romeo jumps rope on the platform. She leads

dialogues.speaker: RING
dialogues.text: and pulls

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: You go, darlin'!

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh Romeo, Romeo... what for ow thou... I dunno, whatever...

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Okay, let's talk defense. Delilah to the on gloves. Tosses Delilah her headgear.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: We're fightin'?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Hell no. We're gonna practice slips. I'm gonna throw some punches, and you're gonna avoid them. If ya can. Delilah puts on her headgear.  37.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Cinch it on tight. (assists her) Now, I want ya to watch my body. Every punch your opponent misses, costs her some energy, right? See where my next punch is coming from, then move your head outta the way. She throws a soft jab at Delilah's head, she evades it.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Good. Keep your eyes on mine. Throws a left hook, Delilah steps out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: This ain't dodgeball. Don't use your feet. Only your head. She throws more punches, a little faster now.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: The idea's to avoid the attack, but use as little energy as possible. Delilah's into it, bobbing her head back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: This is kinda fun. Tandy puts a little more power behind her punches and POP Delilah in the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Owwwwwwwwwww ! (falls to her knees)

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Oh shit. She squats next to Delilah, pulls her hand away from her mouth. Blood pours from a cut on Delilah's lip.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Somebody get me a towel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah sits on a gurney, enclosed by a privacy curtain. She holds a white towel to her lip. She looks down at her hand and notices the impression lef by her engagement ring. Delilah brings the towel down and tries to wipe away the mark.  38. The curtain opens wide and in walks Doctor NATE MORE, 30s widowed, and hasn't combed his hair since.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Are you here for stitches?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh God, please no. I've never had stitches 'fore in my life.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Hold on. Let's have a look. (pulls up a stool) I'm Doctor More. Delilah, is it?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: That's a little intimidating. I haven't had a haircut in months. Delilah makes a scissoring motion with her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: (chuckles) So what brings you here?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I was involved in a boxin' accident.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: A boxing accident. (walks to counter)

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Uh huh. I was learnin' how to do The Slip, and I zigged when I should've zagged. Nate drips solution onto a cotton ball.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: That's too bad. I've got some good news for you though. He leans in and cleanses the wound.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: No stitches. Delilah unabashedly hugs Nate's head, he nearly tumbles.  39.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That's so great! Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: (nose to nose) Be sure to keep it dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah turns on the light, tosses her gym bag on the bed She steps in front of her full-length mirror and inspects her face. A thin adhesive strip rides her upper lip.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh yuck. I look like him.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing? Delilah turns. Mirabelle stands in the doorway, arms fold

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: What're you talkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: Oh my God! What is that?! She hoofs it across the room, dodging SlamMan.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: Is that a cut? Is it deep?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: It's just a tiny one.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: How did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I already told you.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: You haven't told me anything. I hardly see you anymore. Where've you been going?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (mocking her) You mean you don't remember? Mirabelle searches the files in her head.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: The other mornin'. You were havin' breakfast. There was a lot of laughter, as I recall.  40.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: If you're telling me you've taken up boxing, I'm gonna go ballistic.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Momma, you're already there. Mirabelle pulls at her own hair, SCREAMS like a banshee.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if that upsets you. If you need somethin' to hit, try the SlamMan.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: I want that monstrosity out of here! She punches SlamMan in the head. Breaks a nail.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: Good heavens. Now look what you've done. This is all your fault!

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: My fault?!

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: You must have done something. Said something stupid that upset him for him to do that to you.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Did you just call me stupid? Mirabelle inches backward.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Step back, Momma. Let me show you how it's done. She throws on her bag gloves, goes off on SlamMan. Mirabe looks on in horror. Races out clutching her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah spars with Slice, both in headgear. No sign of Ta Delilah bounces around like she's at a disco. Slice toys with her, arms down, smiles ugly through her mouthguard.

dialogues.speaker: SLICE
dialogues.text: That Band-Aid looks like a moustache.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Must stink to know I'm still prettier than you.  41. Slice STINGS her on the side of the head.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Maybe I oughta grow a full beard so you can catch up. Slice ZINGS her on the other side of the head.

dialogues.speaker: SLICE
dialogues.text: Keep talking, SilverSpoon. I'm kinda enjoying this. Shouldn't you be in a ball gown somewhere, cookin' up some grits?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: As a lady, I'm prone to wearin' dresses. Where do rednecks normally shop? Slice laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Did you get your three squares today? I didn't notice any Slim Jim wrappers in the trash. As Delilah sweats, her skin strip begins to peel off.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Is that a new perfume you're wearin'? I never tried Raid. Slice swings, but this time, Delilah slips her punch.

dialogues.speaker: SLICE
dialogues.text: Such a sweet li'l thing, coming in here to learn how to box. Should be married 'n pregnant by now... Tandy hustles into the gym carrying a grocery bag.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Aren't you married? Or don't you have a brother? Her skin strip falls. Slice unloads and CONNECTS on Delil cut, dropping her flat on her back.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Slice! You sloppy shit-bitch! She drops her bag and hops into the ring.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Get away from her!  42. Slice edges out of the way. Blood pours from Delilah's li

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (groggy) I let you down. Tandy uses the bottom of her shirt to press down on the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah sits on a gurney, a towel to her mouth, her eyes bit swollen. Tandy leans next to her as TRAFFIC passes by

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: It's gonna be stitches for sure this time.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Don't worry. You'll still be the prettiest one at the gym.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: I know so.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Why're we sittin' out here anyway?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Because they ran out of room. Nate turns the corner, sees Delilah.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: I should've stayed in sales with all these repeat customers.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: The cut opened, Doctor More.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Uh oh. Another boxing accident?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Nate smiles, he glances over at Tandy and all of a sudden Tandy feels like she's intruding on a private conversatio

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: I'll see ya back at the gym. (goes, stops) Wait. I'm your ride.  43.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That's okay. I'll just call a cab. It's not that far.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Okay. Bye. (leaves)

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (calling) Thanks for drivin' me. She lets go of her towel, Nate inspects her lip.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: You're lucky, Miss Delilah. A little Dermabond should do it. But that's two strikes. Your eyes look swollen to me, too. He rips open a peroxide towelette and cleanses the cut.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Smells nice. Like lemons.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: You know what goes good with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah squeezes lemon into a cup of tea. A topical skin adhesive highlights her upper lip.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: (sips coffee) So you're gonna beat the grits out of your ex-fianc?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: "Deed I am.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: He embarrassed me. And I'd like to return the favor.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Would they even allow that?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: They're gonna have to. Boxers must be good for business, wouldn't you say?  44.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: I'd like not to think of it asa growth industry. Delilah notices his wedding band. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Is your wife a doctor, too?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: No, actually. She passed away.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm really sorry to hear that. She must've been young.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Too young.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Do you have any kids?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: One daughter. Abby.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Does she look like...?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Isabel. They have the exact same eyes. Both at a loss what to say next.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: There's a um... Charity Ball goin' on at the Convention Center on Saturday night. If you think you might be up for it, it'd sure be nice to have a doctor in my corner. You know, in case I get into any fist fights.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: I dunno. Saturday... I think I might have something going on.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That makes one of us.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: What's the charity?  45.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Southern Belles With Fat Lips... Foundation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mirabelle stands with the fridge door open, glaring at Sa

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: I won't stand for this. It's bad enough we spent thousands of dollars on her wedding and have nothing to show for it. But now she's got this cockamamie idea in her head that's gonna threaten her only asset which is her looks. I won't stand for it. You have to talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Charlene eavesdrops.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Maybe it's just a phase she's gotta work herself through.

dialogues.speaker: MIRABELLE
dialogues.text: We're not talking hula hoops and yo- yos, Samuel. She's one facial scar away from bagging groceries at the Piggly Wiggly. (slams fridge door) Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel meanders in the dark toward Delilah's bedroom, her light is on.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Samuel raises his hand to knock, peeks in. Delilah hunches in a blue ball gown, whimpering in front her full-length mirror. Her back to Samuel, she wipes tea from her eyes. A sad look from Samuel and he sneaks away.  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elegant, refined. A HOST of tuxedos and ball gowns. Delilah emerges through a revolving door looking impeccab aside from her TWO BLACK EYES. Her appearance garners her an unfamiliar sort of attentio which shows on her face when she spots two of her Bridesm directing their BEAUS toward a more dignified place to mi Smiling her way and dressed to the nines, is Nate. He hol out his hand, she takes it.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: You did say "boxing," didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (sigh of relief) Yes, I did. I ran out o' concealer. They stroll through the crowd of onlookers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah and Nate eat dinner at a table with six other GUE A few find it difficult not to stare at Delilah's bruises

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (sips wine) So how old's Abby?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Thirteen. Eighth grade philosopher.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: You have a picture? Nate takes out his wallet, an accordion of pictures unrav Straight down into his soup.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Jeez! I'm an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Hurry, she's drownin'! (hands him her napkin) Nate wipes off the pictures, Delilah leans over to see.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: My God, she is just beautiful. Even with minestrone in her hair.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Yes, she is.  47.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: What's she like?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: She's a good egg. With a double yolk, you might say.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: She's definitely got two sides to her. There's the side I hear on the phone a lot with her friends. And then there's sort of a long-distance Abby. That's the one that normally shows up for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Has this been goin' on since... Nate nods. They share a forlorn look. Back to eating. Delilah raises her fork, looks up ata

dialogues.speaker: TABLE ACROSS THE WAY
dialogues.text: where Kelvin and Marney dine, laughing and smiling.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH'S EYES
dialogues.text: glow fuchsia. She puts her fork down.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Would you excuse me for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Thank you. I won't be long. She gets up and glides across the dining hall to

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: They see her drawing near, and freeze with fear.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (addressing table) How're all y'all doin' tonight? Havin' a nice time? The Guests turn, startled, as Delilah beams a smile at th through her black eyes.  48.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Please forgive my appearance. I don't mean to interrupt, I know all y'all're enjoyin' your meal. Isn't it just delicious? Kelvin and Marney trade looks, unsure where the exits are

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Raise your hand if you got the sea bass. She looks around the table, a TIMID COUPLE raises their h

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Itn't it scrumptious?

dialogues.speaker: TIMID HUSBAND
dialogues.text: Very scrumptious, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Goooood. All y'all've had a chance to meet Mr. Wingfield here? She gestures to Kelvin, the Guests nod.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Flyweight boxer. Handsome for his size, don't you think? But I never seen those Peter Jackson movies. What you probably don't know - all but one - is that he left me at the altar. And my guess is, for the woman seated to his left. (Guests gasp and turn) Itn't she sweet? Anyone know who she is?

dialogues.speaker: TIMID WIFE
dialogues.text: Marney, right?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That's right. Marney Cobb. She was my best friend. (Guests gasp again) "Deed, she was. But look at her now. An up-n-comin' homewrecker. Itn't that precious? Now all y'all go on 'n enjoy your dessert. Nite...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah and Nate gaze at each other as they dance.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: You're a natural.  49.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I should be. Started when I was five.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: How many years ago was that?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: You're askin' a lady her age?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: (Jimmy Stewart) A pox upon me for a clumsy lout.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (giggles) _ . . Thanks for comin' with me to this.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Don't mention it. I plan on giving a fat check to the Fat Lip Foundation.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I'm sure they'd... swell with pride.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Naturally.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: You ever been to somethin' like this before?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Yes, I have. A little over two years ago.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Feels sort o' surreal, doesn't it? Funny. I was expectin' my next dance to be with someone 'bout six inches shorter than you.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: I can slouch if you like.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: No, don't do that. I don't want you to do that. Nate spins Delilah.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: What do you do when the happier times all start feelin' surreal?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: I hold on.  50.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Until when?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Until the ride's over. And you have to get off. Delilah looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: It hurts when I smile. Maybe I should stop.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Delilah, if you stop smiling, it'll be the end of all of us.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I'll trade you. One painkiller for every smile.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: That sounds about right.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: The sound of a fight BELL. A leaner Delilah springs out of her corner. Her helmet is color-coordinated with the rest of her outfit. Her opponent, VALERIE VENDETTA, 30, snarly redhead, dance over with confidence. They trade jabs. Valerie throws a couple of straight righ that Delilah parries. Delilah tries a straight right, misses, loses her balance Valerie makes her pay for it with a wicked shot to the ri

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: (slaps the mat) Snap 'n back! Snap 'n back! Don't leave yourself open! Delilah bobs erratically east to west. Valerie connects with a left uppercut. Delilah delivers three left jabs, dropping her opponent b A left hook from Valerie that Delilah slips, she retaliat with one of her own, surprising Valerie and her right tem Delilah loses her balance when she tries for a left upper but enough so to miss a vicious straight right from Valer The BELL. Delilah retreats to her corner. Tandy, Hank and Romeo enter the ring.  51.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CROWD
dialogues.text: Samuel sits alone, his Panama hat pulled down low.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RING
dialogues.text: Hank rubs Vaseline under Delilah's left eye.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Is that non-comedogenic?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Sure. What? Romeo gives her a swig of water.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: You're all over the place out there. Did Slice stick a curling iron down your shorts?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Yes, she did. I'm still gettin' warmed up. (smiles up at Romeo) Romeo laughs, until he sees Tandy's look.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: This girl's just waitin' for ya to lose your balance so she can knock the shit outta ya. Make the bitch wait.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You can do it, Delilah.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Thanks, Hank. The BELL. Delilah comes out of her corner, bobbing less. Valerie starts in with two right uppercuts to Delilah's r Not ready for them, she stiffens up. Delilah comes back with a jab and a straight right, Valer parries them both. She counters with a combination of her own, landing both. Delilah's back to moving helter-skelter. Conscious of her left ribs, she lowers her guard. Valerie lets loose a straight right that drops Delilah flat.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Shit!  52. REFEREE starts the countdown. Delilah doesn't budge an in

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CROWD
dialogues.text: An ashen Samuel stands up.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE WAY
dialogues.text: Nate looks sick to his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RING
dialogues.text: Delilah's counted out. Tandy, Hank and Romeo scramble in.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Delilah! The RING PHYSICIAN, 50s, enters, stoops down to Delilah.

dialogues.speaker: RING PHYSICIAN
dialogues.text: Can you hear me? He checks her airways, tilts her head back.

dialogues.speaker: RING PHYSICIAN
dialogues.text: Can you hear me, Miss MacIntosh?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I do. I do. I dooo... Her eyes slowly open, she looks up at the Ring Physician.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (wistfully) That's all he needed to say. Ring Physician and Tandy look at each other quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dimly lit, a few lights have been punched out. Delilah si on a bench, showered and dressed, morose and lost in her thoughts. A welt surrounds her left eye. Tandy appears in the shadows, Delilah doesn't need to loo

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Sometimes I just don't know who I'm foolin'. (beat) Am I foolin' you?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: "Bout what?  53.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Me. As a boxer.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: If boxing was easy, God wouldn't have invented championship belts.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Can I ask you somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Do you think... I have what it takes?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: No. Delilah turns to face her.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: When ya do, ya won't have to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nate sets a big bowl of spaghetti on the table. His daugh ABBY, 13, anxious eyes and nondescript clothes, adds Silverware and napkins. Nate turns off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I hope you didn't put too much oregano this time.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: There's no such thing as too much oregano. Just add more basil.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (snags a breadstick) If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Doing anything this Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I dunno, why?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: There's someone I'd like you to meet.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Her name's Delilah.  54.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Do I know her?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: If you did, I wouldn't ask you to meet her. Abby looks away. Round One goes to Nate. Round Two

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Where's she from?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Savannah.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: No, I mean how'd you -- never mind.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: She came into the emergency room one day with a busted lip.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Someone beat er up?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Sort of?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: She's a boxer.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Huh. That's sorta dangerous. to Abby. She whips out her cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Do you have to do that now?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (punching buttons) What're you doing with her?

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean, what am I doing with her?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You know.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: No I don't.  55.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Dad, you're a doctor. And today we were putting condoms on plantains in sex ed class. You do know.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: So now you're gonna hold my degree against me? I screwed up the sauce. At least let me keep my degree. Abby smirks at her dad.

dialogues.speaker: NATE
dialogues.text: Plantains? Split decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah, in neon green, practices slips by dodging the weighted end of a swinging rope. Romeo jumps rope nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Did you catch Project Runway last night?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Never miss it.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Man, that guy Vernon's crazy. He had his nose so far up that judge's ass, if she sneezed he would've died.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh I don't like him. I like Alysha. Ev'ry week she makes somethin' different.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I like Inga. Delilah turns toward Hank and gets clonked in the head.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Ow! Romeo swings his rope around to Hank, who does situps.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: She always knows how far to push it before the judges get pissed off. Tandy shows, holding a boom box.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Ya done bonkin' yourself in the head?  56.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: For today, yes.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Good. Come with me. She leads Delilah to the

dialogues.speaker: RING
dialogues.text: and sets the boom box down.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: We need to find you a rhythm. Long one's too mellow for ya, and the short one almost gotcha killed. Ya said you've been taking dancing lessons since you were born?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Give or take a few years.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: You remember the box step?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: It's been a while. Tandy turns on WALTZING music.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Dance with me. You wanna be the man or the woman?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Which would you rather be?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: I asked you first.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Well then I guess that makes you the man. They assume a Closed Position, Tandy as the man. She brin her left foot forward, Delilah brings her right foot back The box step is underway.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Is it coming back to ya?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Pretty much. 'Cept I don't hear my Momma screamin' in the background.  57.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: Good. Ya don't want your opponent to get a read on ya. If they predict where you're going before ya even get there, you're as done as dinner.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: We don't want that.

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: If ya think they are getting a read on ya, I want ya to switch genders.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: That'd be awful expensive, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: TANDY
dialogues.text: No. I mean, dance the man's part.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. Tandy shakes her head, a flicker of a smile as they waltz Meanwhile, the Gym-goers have congregated outside the rin A flustered-looking Slice emerges from the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: SLICE
dialogues.text: What in Holy Hell's she done to this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah, in electric red, jumps rope. A COUPLE bickers nearby. They appear lost. The Wife approaches Delilah, the Husband lags behind eyeing a map.

dialogues.speaker: LOST WIFE
